text.title: part13_Augusten Burroughs on addiction, writing, his family and his new book

p.hi: DS: Did you make a choice--

p: AB: I made a deliberate choice with that book, yeah.

p.hi: DS: Why was the choice made?

p: AB: Because it was the only way I could write that book, and I had to write that book.

p.hi: DS: Did you try to write it funny at first?

p: AB: I was terrified--no. And I know this may turn a lot of people off. Because there are going to be people who approach this book with a smile on their face--

AB: And as soon as they hear the title, A Wolf at the Table, they'll already chuckle. And then as they read it, they'll think, "Well, my God, he's lost it. This isn't funny!" And then the more they read, they'll realize: this is just horrible. I mean, it's just a devastating, terrifying story. But I had to write it for me--and, um, I mean, it's, it's definitely scary, because it's--I don't, you know, I don't want to alienate my readers, or my fans, but you know, I can't think about that.
AB: I can't…I can't write books to sell.

p.hi: DS: But also, too, your fans should realize that you're not one-dimensional.
DS: With your writing, that you don't have a--

p: AB: Well, that's the other thing.

p.hi: DS: It's like, "Oh, we wanna see Data from 'Star Trek' be Data; we don't want to see him in his full range of emotions," you know--

p: AB: I don't want to be just funny, or just sarcastic, because you know I am--
AB: I'm very serious--that's the weird thing; in person, I'm very serious. I'm not so funny. I'm, like, as funny as your dentist. So, this book is…is--it's another side of me.

p.hi: DS: Why do you think you are so serious in person?

p: AB: Well, I get a lot of it out in the books. I used to be funnier, which is funny, ironic.

p.hi: DS: Is it like a purpose-ness? That you're very purpose-driven now, or--?

p: AB: It's not that I'm purpose-driven; I've always been serious. I've always been really, really serious. I've always been very introspective and introverted, and--

p.hi: DS: Do you and Dennis yuk it up at home?

p: AB: Some, yeah. He's on the serious side, too. [Laughs] It's like--whoo! what a fun time--no, we do have fun, we do laugh. We have a very similar sense of humor, very dark It's not to say that I'm always deadly serious; it’s that I'm not a person always "on" you know, in that funny way.
